instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 beeps
threads.message: Hi again, I´ve got this board which was working, I first turned on and work on the computer fine, but when I left it and it whent to sleep I found the problem that was reported. I have 3 beeps as for memory, as it is beeping I measured <SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3_MEM</SIGNAL> = 1.35v, so I just want to know if this model is known for that kind of problems, or is it worth it to reflow the memory chips? thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 beeps
threads.message:
3 beeps code error is caused by bad communication between CPU and RAM; not because of missing RAM voltage.
I don't remember to heard about classic issue related to this problem on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 beeps
threads.message:
You should check at least <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>MEM_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, but it's probably an issue related to the RAM chip themselves.

On <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> it can be caused by physical stress pretty much like <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and a reflow may fix it for long enough, but on newer <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> the issue has been mitigated with better board support so it's much less likely to happen (doesn't mean it cannot happen). This can also result in damaged pads which would not be reasonably repairable.
Of course it can be failed RAM chips even though it doesn't happen often.
Still, a RAM reflow followed by several passes of Memtest is worth a shot…
